so... do not stay positive. that sucks. id be so upset. do something to express how you are feeling. write a letter, or make an artwork, or go for a run, or beat the shit out of a punching bag... etc. pick something, release all those emotions you are feeling! be angry! be frustrated! be upset! fuck staying positive. you are allowed to feel bad too. you do not have to be positive all the time. if you keep ignoring your emotions, you will hate yourself even more. the self-harm will creep in because its the only way left to express yourself - you need to get ahead of it ... express yourself in other ways, then it will not have the same power behind it. then, once you have thrown all those emotions out, expressed them all and probably cried for an hour or more, then ... take a deep breath and pull yourself together. be nice to yourself for the next day or two, while you are recovering, and then you can go back to trying to stay positive. for now though... take a break from the positivity. in a safe way. good luck 3 i hope this helps, i am drawing from my own experiences with self-harm so if it sounds like rubbish ... feel free to ignore

from when i was a child my mother called me a parasite and told me that if i did not do my duty and did well in education she would kick me out the moment i was of age. back then i had no choice but to do well in school so my life would not be any more hellish than it already was. but of course as a grew older i naturally started to dream of better things. i did not just work so my life would not be any worse, i worked so i could make my life better. i worked to move out, to study abroad, to have a career i like, to be the best i can be and to have the best life possible. you have to know intrinsically that you are not the problem, your mother is. your mother is not normal and you have to adapt to that. unfortunately trauma sticks. it will never not affect you. you can only learn to minimize it and push it aside. sometimes, much like a disability, it can stop us from doing things others do all the time and take from granted. some people will never be able to walk, and some people will never be able to have sex because of trauma. you have the right to go at your own pace and take care of yourself as you see fit. and if you cannot do something because its too much for you then that is okay.

i completely agree, there is no going back. what i have found is that you keep going until you find a new way of living... one that accepts you might have this feeling, you might be damaged, but it will not stop you finding things you like and it will not stop you living. its so, so unfair that you have this condition that makes things harder for absolutely no reason, but even if it never goes away, you can still take time, and still find a way to live with it. one person i knew a long time ago described it something like i still have the shadows on the edges of my mind, and sometimes they still grow darker, but i have found a way to live in the lighter part of my mind and i know how to enjoy the flashes of brilliant light when they happen. i think that is a good way to describe it. my mental health problems are not going to go away, and i have to accept that, but i can still improve how i live with these problems so that my quality of life improves. i imagine its similar to any other disability when you first get it - at first it seems impossible, then with time you can adapt and learn new ways of doing things and quality of life improves, even if you can never go back to how you were before. some people really can be cured, but others cannot, and that is ok. keep living anyway, and keep trying things, because it always takes time to adapt and find what works. take care of yourself. i am sorry this is happening to you

if you have felt otherwise before, what led you to change your mind?

why are you going back to uni if it makes you overwhelmed and stressed, you do not want to do psychology anymore, and you already had a job you loved anyway? it does not sound like you want to go back to uni at all. i suggest you reconsider this course of action. i think you should speak to your doctor or any other specialist you are seeing about this, but i would not rush to abandon the job that you enjoy. you were able to do the job just fine before, so i think its likely that you will be able to do it again once the extra stress is taken off. i think, at the very least, you should wait a while and see how you feel about work once your stress has leveled out again. if you still want to quit work after your stress levels have stabilised give it at least a few weeks, then it might be time to talk to work about scaling back or even quitting, but do not do it without a plan of what you are going to do next. quitting in order to stay home and do nothing is not going to help. quitting or taking a break in order to get more intense therapy and work hard on your mental health is ok but do it with the support of your care team, not on a whim. quitting to heal may also be ok, but its important you have a plan of how that will work, the timeframe, and what you will do next. i think, also, if you do decide you need a break, you should try to take time off from your job rather than quit it entirely if possible, i know not all workplaces would allow this. i know what its like being so scared and i wish i could help you i have been scared like that too. please contact any support you have in place friends and family, as well as doctors, psychologists, counsellors... and discuss with them before you decide anything. find someone you trust and feel safe with who knows you well, because their advice will probably be far better than mine. right now you are doing too much, and that is what your anxiety is telling you. you need to be selective in what you remove from your life i am 60 and i am still not prepared. at 40, after 20 years of an abusive marriage, i got a divorce and then i was homeless with a 9 year old son. at 45, i was homeless again. at 55, i got sick and had to leave my dream job and now i cannot work any more. the only adult thing i learned to do was pay the important bills first , at the beginning of the month...rent, electricity, phone, and car insurance. if i have anything left, i might get some food. after being homeless the second time, i realized all those years of telling myself that things would get better if i tried hard enough to keep my family together, were wasted on a fucking lie. start teaching yourself to be self-sufficient. the feeling you get from your accomplishments will shape you into an amazing human person.

from when i was a child my mother called me a parasite and told me that if i did not do my duty and did well in education she would kick me out the moment i was of age. back then i had no choice but to do well in school so my life would not be any more hellish than it already was. but of course as a grew older i naturally started to dream of better things. i did not just work so my life would not be any worse, i worked so i could make my life better. i worked to move out, to study abroad, to have a career i like, to be the best i can be and to have the best life possible. you have to know intrinsically that you are not the problem, your mother is. your mother is not normal and you have to adapt to that. unfortunately trauma sticks. it will never not affect you. you can only learn to minimize it and push it aside. sometimes, much like a disability, it can stop us from doing things others do all the time and take from granted. some people will never be able to walk, and some people will never be able to have sex because of trauma. you have the right to go at your own pace and take care of yourself as you see fit. and if you cannot do something because its too much for you then that is okay.

i completely agree, there is no going back. what i have found is that you keep going until you find a new way of living... one that accepts you might have this feeling, you might be damaged, but it will not stop you finding things you like and it will not stop you living. its so, so unfair that you have this condition that makes things harder for absolutely no reason, but even if it never goes away, you can still take time, and still find a way to live with it. one person i knew a long time ago described it something like i still have the shadows on the edges of my mind, and sometimes they still grow darker, but i have found a way to live in the lighter part of my mind and i know how to enjoy the flashes of brilliant light when they happen. i think that is a good way to describe it. my mental health problems are not going to go away, and i have to accept that, but i can still improve how i live with these problems so that my quality of life improves. i imagine its similar to any other disability when you first get it - at first it seems impossible, then with time you can adapt and learn new ways of doing things and quality of life improves, even if you can never go back to how you were before. some people really can be cured, but others cannot, and that is ok. keep living anyway, and keep trying things, because it always takes time to adapt and find what works. take care of yourself. i am sorry this is happening to you

what you are feeling is the effect of social isolation. i spent about 6 months in a similar situation, not really interacting with anyone, and it was ... bad. you do lose yourself. you start dissociating that is the not real feeling you have. social isolation also makes any mental health conditions you have worse. according to the internet url it can also because or worsen headaches, so ... i do not know what you can do about that. not being able to do your hobbies is probably making all of this worse, too. i think you should probably try to reconnect with the outside world. maybe get some really dark glasses, like blind people wear? or even just wear a blindfold or something if being outside your room is too bright. then you can start going for walks around your house, or in your yard with your mum or a friend, if you cannot see. maybe you could also start going out at night, to parks or someplace there will not be too many bright lights but be careful of safety in that case, do not go wandering in an alleyway alone at midnight, and always tell someone where you are going. you could also try hanging out with your family or friends at your house, or their houses, so that you get a chance for more interaction but in an environment you can control so that hopefully the headaches are less bad. if too many people at once is too loud you could also invite just one or two at a time. id also recommend keeping in touch with people online - the more video calls you can do, the better, because the way you connect with someone is way better than if you are just texting them. i do not think online-only is the best way to go but it is probably the easiest, so you could start with that. you should also either try to find a new hobby that is headache-compatible, or try to modify your old hobbies so that you can still do them. i guess you could try listening to podcasts? or doing some sort of craft ceramics? origami? drawing? knitting? or maybe you could try exercising more? reading? whatever works and does not make your headaches worse even if you have to do it in very short periods of time with lots of rest inbetween. i do not know what your regular hobbies include but maybe there are videos of other people doing them that you could watch? or with just the audio? or podcasts about your hobbies? or maybe you could try doing a more low-key variation of a hobby, like for a few minutes at a time or with some modifications to make it better for your headaches.

if you want to entirely avoid copycats, do not give any method of suicide. just let your character learn that this person has taken their own life, but no one will tell the character how. if you give a method, someone can copy it. this is based on mental health education i have done in the past, i am not just making this up. the safest way to talk about suicide is to not include methods or even specific locations at all. if you need a dramatic scene where your character learns about it, they could learn it from the dead characters family, or they could hear the announcement at school, or their parentsfriend could tell them about it. if they hear the news third-hand, its understandable that they will not have the full information. then make sure you show the outcome realistically - do not glorify the suicide, but do show the real-world consequences for example the hurt and grief of the characters family, friends, acquaintances... etc. . your readers should read it and think this is tragic and awful. there should be no possible way they could read it and think suicide was a good solution for that person, and definitely no way they could read it and think that looks like a good method, maybe ill try it.

i am a woman, 28. i am really emotional and used to cry a lot as a teenager and also early 20s. in recent years i had not really had any reason to do so, except a break up for which i might have cried for a few minutes. this fall i started feeling really sad but could not cry. it just would not happen, no matter how much i tried. i realised i was actively calming myself down before i felt bad enough to cry. with introspection i realised i was trying to accept my moms lack of acceptance of my orientation i am bi, my last relationship was with a woman and since she was also the person who was the most bothered, who called me too emotional every time i cried, i could not bring myself to do it. what helped was noticing and thinking about what brought me to nearly cry, and what did i do after that in order to not cry. i started being able to anticipate this is a tear-worthy situation!. i then slowly unlearned the coping mechanisms that i had put in place to keep myself from crying and after a few months found myself crying violently after a minor sad moment on a show i was watching. i guess i was catching up. doing better on that front now

if at all possible, find someone you can talk to. maybe you could try online therapy as its reasonably anonymous? or maybe you could share your emotions with a friend you trust, even if its something you have never done before your mother dying is a huge thing, people will understand if you behave differently due to that. if you cannot find therapy or a friend, you can still express it all by writing it down or making an artwork, or a song, or even just exercising to push out all the emotions. do not be afraid to baby yourself a bit. if you want to curl up in a fluffy blanket and cry, let it happen, even if it feels a bit dumb. you are allowed to be sad and you are allowed to be hurting. in time you should be able to pull yourself back together and do things, but grief is hard, so be ready for it to hit you several times as you rebuild.

you are probably just used to the level of fatigue. the awake but unresponsive seems like a sign of that. i worked in the events industry and would work 7am to midnight or later for days or weeks at a time and that is how i would feel. it felt totally normal and i asked myself what the fuss about the 8hnight was, but when i got home and resumed a healthier schedule of 78h a night i realised how much more rested i was and that i had really been sleep deprived. the health consequences you can have from prolonged lack of sleep are more in the long run than immediate. 16yos are mostly sturdy things that adapt and react. but it puts you at a greater risk for heart attacks soon in life, for example wanted to link the study i had read about it but cannot find it. if you asked here it must be because you have some concernthoughts. you are probably smart enough to think of ways you could stop playing earlier and also how to stick to that. ask your parents to help you be consistent, or a sibling or even gamer buddies if you play online. i hear heart attacks are very painful.

yesterday seemed normal. i had a string of good days, so i was just pushed myself to make breakfast and watch some tv. i do not remember how it started but soon i was trapped in my bed crying. my pillow was soaked. whenever i thought about doing anything like asking a friend for help or brushing my teeth, there was such a torrent of negative thoughts and i would start crying again. i was so violently sad and scared i would be stuck for the rest of the day, maybe the week. i was so focused on not crying that i was stuck laying there. after a length of time i lost track, i pulled myself together enough to watch a movie. i felt so agitated after what happened to me. i could not enjoy the movie, i was so uncomfortable and sad that i could not stand just laying down and watching the movie. then, after the agitation, i felt drained. it was miserable, but i was able to finally talk to someone and feel a bit better. i rarely feel this out of control. i have felt hopeless, numb, and suicidal before, but this time was so overwhelming. has anyone felt the same? i do not notice this specific feeling described often.

that sounds so hard i am sorry the rapid mood swings must be exhausting. its common for teenagers to have mood swings and its even more likely if they have mental health conditions. if you are living in an abusive situation you might have cptsd which would definitely make things worse. if you have bpd like you mentioned in your post, a common symptom of that is also extreme and rapid mood changes. so, all in all, it sounds like you are living in the perfect situation to have a lot of rapid mood changes and so, while it sucks, its probably something to be expected in your situation and its not your fault. i think if you can find a therapist that specialises in teens who have experienced trauma and abuse, that will likely be the most helpful to you. in the meantime, do your best to stay alive. if you ever reach a point where you are not sure you can keep living, call yourself an ambulance and go to hospital. it will probably suck but at least you will be alive. if there is any chance you can move away from your abuser like, live with someone else that would be a good idea too but i know that is not always possible. take care of yourself.

what you are feeling is the effect of social isolation. i spent about 6 months in a similar situation, not really interacting with anyone, and it was ... bad. you do lose yourself. you start dissociating that is the not real feeling you have. social isolation also makes any mental health conditions you have worse. according to the internet url it can also because or worsen headaches, so ... i do not know what you can do about that. not being able to do your hobbies is probably making all of this worse, too. i think you should probably try to reconnect with the outside world. maybe get some really dark glasses, like blind people wear? or even just wear a blindfold or something if being outside your room is too bright. then you can start going for walks around your house, or in your yard with your mum or a friend, if you cannot see. maybe you could also start going out at night, to parks or someplace there will not be too many bright lights but be careful of safety in that case, do not go wandering in an alleyway alone at midnight, and always tell someone where you are going. you could also try hanging out with your family or friends at your house, or their houses, so that you get a chance for more interaction but in an environment you can control so that hopefully the headaches are less bad. if too many people at once is too loud you could also invite just one or two at a time. id also recommend keeping in touch with people online - the more video calls you can do, the better, because the way you connect with someone is way better than if you are just texting them. i do not think online-only is the best way to go but it is probably the easiest, so you could start with that. you should also either try to find a new hobby that is headache-compatible, or try to modify your old hobbies so that you can still do them. i guess you could try listening to podcasts? or doing some sort of craft ceramics? origami? drawing? knitting? or maybe you could try exercising more? reading? whatever works and does not make your headaches worse even if you have to do it in very short periods of time with lots of rest inbetween. i do not know what your regular hobbies include but maybe there are videos of other people doing them that you could watch? or with just the audio? or podcasts about your hobbies? or maybe you could try doing a more low-key variation of a hobby, like for a few minutes at a time or with some modifications to make it better for your headaches.
but then that is not a passion, just something you might be interested in.

you are missing out on a lot, yes. relationships are complex and allow you to explore a lot of different emotions and experiences that you would not get without a close intimate relationship. however, if you are happy with that, that is fine. there are a lot of experiences that people choose to miss out on. if you never go skydiving, you are missing out on the emotions and experiences that go along with that, but many people choose to miss those and they are still perfectly happy. if you never have children, you are missing out on emotions and experiences that go along with that, but many people choose not to have children or they are unable to and they still have happy lives. my point is, you can choose not to experience some things and still have a happy life, and that is up to you. and if you are happy without a relationship, stop reading here, because the rest is about how to find relationships. if you want a relationship, that is ok too. there are different types of relationships you can have casual or short-term relationship. seriouscommitted relationship if you want a short-term relationship, its a lot easier to get into, because long-term compatibility is not really a consideration. a lot of people do more short-term relationships when they are young teenagers, early 20s, so you are still in time to get involved in that if you want to. basically, the way you get into a short-term relationship is you think do i get on ok with this person? great! let us go on a date. then, if the date goes well, you continue the relationship until you come across something you cannot accept or until you want to end it for some other reason. if the date goes badly, you tell them its not working out and do not see them again. short-term relationships are easy to get into because the bar to start one is very low. you can probably find suitable partners for this on dating sites. if you are looking for a serious, committed relationship, its a lot harder to find because 90 of the dating pool gets rejected automatically. they might be good people, and fun to spend time with, but you do not want to spend the rest of your life with them and so you do not date them if you are thinking long-term. it sounds like maybe you are wired to look for more serious relationships, so it makes sense you have not found the right person yet. a lot of people settle down more once they reach their mid to late 20s, so before that point, its harder to find someone for a serious long-term relationship not impossible, just harder. its also harder to know where to look, because dating sites have a lot of people seeking casual relationships and very few looking for something more serious. i think the best way to find suitable partners for long-term relationships is just to meet a lot of people and make lots of friends, then allow relationships to escalate romanticallysexually if you feel the connection and it feels right. you might notice that short-term dating would lead into this quite well because it involves meeting and dating a lot of people - for some people its very effective, but for others the series of dates is exhausting. if you are in the find it exhausting category, its better to find someone you connect with as friends before you start dating. for me personally, when i am looking for a partner, i start looking for new friends. both of my long-term partners have been people who i initially described as a friend then became a fwb, then fwbbest friend, and then decided to start dating.

honestly, you cannot escape being you. do what you can to make being you more enjoyable. make time for fun things that make you feel good about yourself exercise, hanging out with friends, bubble-baths... whatever works for you. in the long-term, see if you can find a job where the people you work with are good people i understand that may be impossible for now, but make it a long-term goal that you work towards. if you are stuck in miserable jobs because you have no skills, look into training opportunities. even if you have trouble learning new things, there will be training opportunities aimed at people with difficulty learning things. they might be rare or hard to find or difficult to get to, but they exist. find out one that you would like to do, then find out what you will need so you can do it, then work on getting those things. it might take a long time, but you can do it. for the short-term, a lot of people use drugs or alcohol. do not do that, it will make things worse. you could try other forms of escapism, like reading books, or roleplaying online, or joining a community where no one knows the real you and you just enjoy it. those ones are more healthy and worthwhile for you.

what i get from your post is that you do not like your body very much. is there a good reason for that? what are you basing it on? for me, once i started appreciating my body, it changed how i saw everything. it was not because i was more physically attractive in fact it is impossible for it to be related to that, i meet people online and usually without photos being exchanged until we already have a connection. it was because my confidence in myself changed. i realised that i do have value that i bring, and i started projecting that. i am not the most physically attractive person ever, but i am able to use my body to live and accomplish my goals and to bring pleasure to myself and others both sexual and nonsexual pleasures. it sounds like you do not value anything that you are offering, and it comes across to potential partners. if you do not think you are worth it, why would they? if you think you are deeply unattractive, who are they to argue with you? your current partner has obviously seen through your feelings of unworthiness to understand what does make you attractive, and i think you should speak to her about that. take on board the positives she sees. they are real. they are you. own them. show them off! do not start with my most important feature is my body, which by the way is extremely unattractive. no one is going to be attracted to that. start with i have an amazing sense of humour or i have really soft hair that is nice to touch or i am extremely generous and giving ... any of the positive qualities that you possess. your girlfriend probably has some weak points too, but they are not the first thing you notice about her and they are not what defines her. you need to make your own weak points less of a defining feature too.

i would try some non-medication-based things first. e.g. try not using your phone for an hour before bed every night for a week, try meditating before bed every night for a week. after that if you are still not able to sleep then you should see a sleep specialist. they can diagnose and treat sleep disorders like insomnia, if you have that. they can also advise on how to use melatonin correctly. the sleep specialist i saw said that most forms of melatonin are actually detrimental to healthy sleep patterns, but taking some of the right type at the right times, as a short-term measure, can help.

it sounds like you could have some problem with sleep, perhaps? it also sounds like you might have some problems with anxiety or depression of some sort. problems with sleep and anxietydepression usually feed off each other so it is hard to know what causes the other. it could also be a physical health issue causing you to be more tired and have trouble thinking clearly, which would affect both sleep and anxietydepression levels. i think you do need to see a doctor, because it is impossible to know what the underlying because is without medical help. they can help to diagnose you and hopefully then you can make progress towards recovery.

it sounds like you are uncomfortable with your eating behaviours and that you do not feel like you are fully in control of them. that is not healthy or normal, so you are eating is disordered. i personally believe that specific eating disorders like anorexia, bulimia, orthorexia, and ednos are purely medical tools to describe how someone is disordered eating is manifesting at one point in time, and so they are not useful or relevant outside of a clinical context, as disordered eating behaviours and attitudes are dynamic and highly individual. all that matters is that you are struggling and you deserve and need support.

i have made this discovery very recently. all through my life i have had trouble concentrating, thinking straight, been exhausted all through the day, stomach complaints, headaches, muscle and joint pain, anxiety, not really being able to function socially, i have also always been underweight despite seemingly eating gargantuan dinners. a long old laundry list of chronic issues that i figured were just the way i had to live and that i must have something fundamentally wrong with me. turns out its just that i never used to eat breakfast. then id just scarf down a sandwich for lunch, and would not eat a full meal until dinner in the evening, where id have seconds and sometimes third portions. then id wonder why i was full of energy and wide awake at night when the day had been such a struggle. since i started making sure i am actually eating consistently through the day, most of my issues listed above have cleared up completely.

1555 is not over eating, its likely that its below your tdee, which would be under eating and in the case that its above or equal to your tdee, chances are you have been eating much less for an extended period of time, which means that your body still has to recover. one day of eating at maintenance is not going to cancel out any of the damage done from weeks of restriction to feel a little better, try getting some electrolytes in you, basically you are just looking for sodium salty foods, potassium fruits, calcium dairy, magnesium green veggies, nuts, and phosphorus white meat, nuts, dairy

normally i can stop a binge in its tracks by drinking 1l of water, going for a walk, and drinking tea with milk and sugar or hot chocolate, this kind of eliminates the possibility of it being a boredomcraving binge, and let us me feel a little more comfortable with eating more since i feel like i need it. so if i am still struggling after all that, i decide how many calories i am ok with, normally at or slightly above my tdee, and i make sure to drink loads of water in between foods. once i hit my limit i have another mug of teahot chocolate and go to my room to get away from any other foods, i never eat in my room so that i do not associate being in there with food. what works for me is changing the urge to bing away from being a loss of control, and instead towards a form of fucked up self care, i remind myself that eating around my tdee for a day will not make me gain real weight, its just like pressing the pause button on losing, and that the reason i want to binge is because my body needs nutrients, and because i cannot eat this much every day, i need to be mindful about my choices.

good luck! stay strong! pcos patient too its hard to keep eating well and exercising when something like this affects your ability of keeping your desired weight so much. and my family has been obsessing about my weight since i was 7 and looking back at pictures it barely makes sense, so i feel you. hope you are feeling better now. sharing my experience maybe it can give you some tips. i had a brush with diabetes too, due to pcos managed to kick it in the ass with a lot of discipline, 3 very tough years and that motivated me quite a bit. i gained, lost, then gained again. at all times, regardless of my weight, i tell myself that if i am eating reasonably not depriving myself but paying attention to sugars and if i am making an effort to be active whenever i can, then that is what matters. the number on the scale is just a number, i know i am doing my best at most times and that is going to have to be enough. i also learned to love my body, will not lie its harder some times, but we can get there. you do not need to be slim to be healthy and being healthy is the most important part. get a nutritionist if you can, even just 23 appointments to set a good diet and adjust it will help, there are specificities to losing weight when you have pcos. if you cannot do that, my advice is low sugar meals in the evening, less fruit than the average person, lean meats and fish in the evening to feel full faster, full grain cereal at all times, as little alcohol as possible. in terms of exercise strength training, helps your methabolism pick up a notch, can fuel your weight loss. keep in mind it might take you a while for me its about 56 weeks to start losing weight. do not underestimate the importance of sleep and of keeping cortisol levels down, if you are stressed add some short 510 min relaxing yoga or meditation routines to your day.

i have a few things that help me, but not sure how helpful any of them will be for you since everyone is different is it possible to reduce the amount of things causing you stress? i know its not good to avoid things, but at the same time, they need to be approached in a structured way so that you are not causing more problems than you solve. if there are some non-essential things or things that can be postponed until you are more stable, that might be worth doing. just do not put them off forever - rescheduling is ok, but forgetting about them forever is not helpful. setting aside a significant portion of time each day to process everything has really worked for me. i have at least two hours of time where i am by myself without anyone around me, so that i can process things. as part of that, i spend at least half an hour per night writing down everything that is on my mind because that is what helps me to process. sexmasturbation. if you are storing stress in your body, releasing it through sexual activity could be helpful. ritual. i do not know if this will help you, but when i am somewhere i feel very safe or with someone i feel safe with i have specific things that i always do. when i am at home and need to feel safe, it helps to do the same things and try to create that feeling of safety even if i do not currently have access to the thingspeople that usually because it. meditationvisualisation. i am sure you have tried this too but meditating and visualising really helps me when i am getting overly stressed. i like to breathe in, and imagine a light blue balloon of inner calm expanding and reinforcing inside me ... and then i breathe out, and let the rough lumps of dark red tension and stress evaporate. grounding exercises. like, 5 things i see, 4 things i can touch.... it can help a lot when i am feeling overwhelmed and start disconnecting from everything. if the environment i am in is causing me stress, sometimes i prefer to use this to ground myself somewhere else - like ill imagine myself sitting somewhere peaceful near a river, and use the grounding exercise to help me imagine it more clearly so i can relax there. communication with everyone you care about. i am sure you are already doing this one but it is really important. i find that when i do not talk to people i love about my problems, everything gets much much worse. if the people you love are not currently available, you can write them lettersemails even if you do not actually send it, its helpful to lay everything out and then to imagine the persons responses if you know them well. having a plan and knowing what steps i am taking to improve things. it sounds like, from your post, that you have this one covered, but i find that i always get more anxious if i do not have a plan even if the plan is wait and find out what happens next or make it up as i go along. if you find any good ways of living in constant fear id love to hear them too, because i have the same problem. one day at a time, one step at a time is about all i have found that helps, even if its not a solution.

i do feel this way sometimes and have felt so in the past too. sometimes it can last months, other times it will last for a few hours. i have learned to 1. think my way out of it. i have many things i like in my life, that are not achievements or goals but that make my life very enjoyable and even happy at times my parents brother, the volunteering activities i do, i like the rented place i live in. of course some of these things i have had to do work in the past to find them and improve them my relationship with my parents, finding a pass time that really suited me, apartment hunting, decorating and the upkeep that goes into a pleasant living environment. 2. i am old enough and lucky enough to have met people with varied life stories. those that found their career, got married, bought a home later in life and are now fulfilled and happy. those that did not do all of those things and are also happy to have done it their way. at 32 my mom had spent 8y in germany studying part time to become a translator a d working odd or demeaning jobs, she was unmarried, did not own anything except for an old car and she could not find a job. she was stuck giving german classes to spoiled highschool kids. 10y later she had a great well paying job as a translator, a husband, two children and an apartment in a part of town she liked. i try to take things in my hands as much as i can to make things i want happen and tell myself it does not all need to happen or it does not need to happen now.

i have a few things that help me, but not sure how helpful any of them will be for you since everyone is different is it possible to reduce the amount of things causing you stress? i know its not good to avoid things, but at the same time, they need to be approached in a structured way so that you are not causing more problems than you solve. if there are some non-essential things or things that can be postponed until you are more stable, that might be worth doing. just do not put them off forever - rescheduling is ok, but forgetting about them forever is not helpful. setting aside a significant portion of time each day to process everything has really worked for me. i have at least two hours of time where i am by myself without anyone around me, so that i can process things. as part of that, i spend at least half an hour per night writing down everything that is on my mind because that is what helps me to process. sexmasturbation. if you are storing stress in your body, releasing it through sexual activity could be helpful. ritual. i do not know if this will help you, but when i am somewhere i feel very safe or with someone i feel safe with i have specific things that i always do. when i am at home and need to feel safe, it helps to do the same things and try to create that feeling of safety even if i do not currently have access to the thingspeople that usually because it. meditationvisualisation. i am sure you have tried this too but meditating and visualising really helps me when i am getting overly stressed. i like to breathe in, and imagine a light blue balloon of inner calm expanding and reinforcing inside me ... and then i breathe out, and let the rough lumps of dark red tension and stress evaporate. grounding exercises. like, 5 things i see, 4 things i can touch.... it can help a lot when i am feeling overwhelmed and start disconnecting from everything. if the environment i am in is causing me stress, sometimes i prefer to use this to ground myself somewhere else - like ill imagine myself sitting somewhere peaceful near a river, and use the grounding exercise to help me imagine it more clearly so i can relax there. communication with everyone you care about. i am sure you are already doing this one but it is really important. i find that when i do not talk to people i love about my problems, everything gets much much worse. if the people you love are not currently available, you can write them lettersemails even if you do not actually send it, its helpful to lay everything out and then to imagine the persons responses if you know them well. having a plan and knowing what steps i am taking to improve things. it sounds like, from your post, that you have this one covered, but i find that i always get more anxious if i do not have a plan even if the plan is wait and find out what happens next or make it up as i go along. if you find any good ways of living in constant fear id love to hear them too, because i have the same problem. one day at a time, one step at a time is about all i have found that helps, even if its not a solution.

pick one thing you feel like you would be able to improve and start from that. i had to improve my lifediet because of medical conditions more than one at once! yay! and i really like a lot of the changes i made, kept most of them. want to get out of the house more? start with 1h more a week volunteering, walking around your neighbourhood. want to get fit? start moving, again 2030 min a day try it all yoga videos, walks, running and fitness apps. want to eat better? find 1 attractive healthiery recipe a week and make it for yourself and your mom on sundays or saturday nights. though i would leave food last, its such a big part of life its really hard to change eating habits, especially when you are not feeling super well - just a suggestion try beans! they are extra tasty and an awesome alternative to meat and burgers you are 30 and unemployed, which means you have time on your hands and a lot of life ahead of you. try everything good you can think of and keep doing what you like. hate yoga? drop it. love walks in nature? take more than one a week, then maybe join a local walking group, then maybe move on to hiking? i know it takes willpower to make changes, but willpower is something you build. so try this, take one step at a time, do what you like again and move towards a happier you. happier you will have an easier time looking forgetting a job and making the big changes too. do not hesitate to look for support groups, counseling or to go to therapy if you can, even if you are not sure you need it. if you find out you do, its great to start getting better by doing that.
